Sponges 2. 
Monospecific aggregafionz a variefy of specific processes Take place in se-
quence during aggregaTion which are To observe. You will have To waTch The
culTures aT various infervals during The nexT 24 hours or so and Try To answer The
following quesTions. Carefuliy record The Time aT which observafions are made.
Do your observafions primarily on Microciona buT noTe differences wiTh The oTher
sponges.
a) Take a small piece of Microciona and express iT Through bolTing clofh on To
a slide and cover wiTh a cover slip. Make observafions of This aT Times during
The nexT hour adding fluid aT The cover slip edge To avoid evaporaTion. You may
be aided in This by puffing vaseline on Three edges of The coverslip before
puTTing iT on The fluid.
The sTrucTure of The reunifion mass and The cells involved are discussed in
papers by wilson and by GalTsoff, copies of which are available in The laborafory.
Many of The cell Types, The which forms The surface layer of The inTacT
sponge, and all skelefal elemenfs are refained by The bolTing cloTh. Wilson con-
siders Three Types as represenfed among The free cells passing Through The cloTh:
The choanocyTes, which remain specific (alfhough reTracTing Their collars and
flagella in many cases) and produce a new lining for The inTernal caviTies; (2)
cells wiTh nucleolaTe nuclei and a variable degree of granulafion in The cyTosome;
and (3) non-nucleolaTe cells possessing fine cyToplasmic granules of uniform size
which give The cells a grayish color. Wilson regards The nucleolafe cells as
primordial cells, which produce in The reunifion mass, as in The inTacT sponge,
skeleTal and reproducfive cells. The non-nucleolaTe cells produce The 
which covers The body and lines Those infernal spaces noT possessing choanocyTes.
Some indicaTions of cell Types may be learned from your fresh preparaTions, buT
fixed and sTained maferial has been found more saTisfacTory. Do noT spend Too
much Time Trying To idenTify The differenT Types of cells. 
b) AT approximafely hourly inTervals for 3 or 4 hours use a small pipeffe To blow
wafer aT The reuniTion masses. when does a change in behavior of The masses occur?
c) AfTer masses appear make some efforT To measure The size of some of The masses
during The day (say, every 2 hours) by placing a millimeTer rule beneafh The
sTender. Do This especially for Microciona expressages of differenT diluTions
and compare.
d) Place a coverslip on a slide from dish no. 5 affer 2-3 hours and observe The
masses. Are The masses smooTh or rough edged? By carefully focusing on The
surface of a mass see if you can see granulaTed cells wiTh a clear circular space
in Them ("gray cells"). Try again in 4-5 hours, eTc. when They appear you will
noTice The change in surface Texfure of The masses, seen especially aT The edge
of a mass. lf you are careful, you can refurn The slide To The fingerbowl and
remove The coverslip under waTer wiThouT dislodging Too many aggregafes.
e) Rough-edge masses may be combined by pushing Them TogeTher wiTh glass needles
or They may be cuf in half wiTh crossed needles. Wilson and Penney (l93O) say
ThaT masses of l-2 mm. will form The mosT compleTely regeneraTed sponges. You
should combine or divide several masses on slides in finger bowls (no. 5 above)
for laTer observafions.
f) ln from l8~24 hours many masses will be firmly affached by visible exTensions
of The aggregafe. Observe such aggregafes on a slide and on a coverslip from
dish no. 6 inverfed inTo sea wafer in a depression slide (or on an ordinary slide).
Describe The aTTachmenTs and The shapes of The masses.
